headline.main: A CONVERSATION WITH -- Herman Taylor; Mississippi's 'Heart Man' Examines Links Between Race and Disease

docs.abstract: Interview with Dr Herman A Taylor discusses his work helping African-Americans living around Jackson, Miss, improve their health and make better life style choices; emphasizes concerns about obesity and its long term effects on black Americans; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: When Dr. Herman A. Taylor Jr. goes for breakfast in this city of 180,000, he orders carefully: granola, fresh fruit. ''People look at what I put on my tray,'' he said on a recent morning at the Broad Street Bakery, a local cafe. ''They wonder if I practice what I preach.'' Around Jackson, where a common breakfast can be eggs fried in lard, Dr. Taylor, a University of Mississippi cardiologist, is known as ''heart man.'' He is the director of the Jackson Heart Study, the largest epidemiological investigation ever undertaken to discover the links between cardiovascular disease and race.
docs.snippet: Dr. Herman A. Taylor Jr. directs the largest epidemiological investigation into the links between cardiovascular disease and race.

headline.main: His Subject: Highly Evolved And Exquisitely Thirsty

docs.abstract: Mark Siddall of American Museum of Natural History has made study of leeches his life's work; describes his passion for leeches and his continued involvement in evolutionary study of how leeches became blood-suckers; Food and Drug Administration in 2004 approved use of Hirudo medicinalis leech as medical device used primarily in reattachment of human body parts; photos; drawing (L)
docs.lead_paragraph: The tub full of leeches sat on a table in Mark Siddall's office at the American Museum of Natural History. The leeches, each an inch long and covered in orange polka dots, were swimming lazily through the water. One leech in particular attracted Dr. Siddall's attention. It had suddenly begun undulating up and down in graceful curves, pushing water along its body so that it could draw more oxygen into its skin.
docs.snippet: Mark Siddall has traced how an ordinary worm hundreds of millions of years ago gave rise to sophisticated bloodsucking leeches around the world.

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: Dr. Mark Siddall, co-curator of invertebrate zoology at the American Museum of Natural History, defends the leech and says our fear of them is learned behavior. (Producer: Craig Duff)

multimedia.caption: Defending the Leech
multimedia.credit: Dr. Mark Siddall, co-curator of invertebrate zoology at the American Museum of Natural History, defends the leech and says our fear of them is learned behavior. (Producer: Craig Duff)

headline.main: Few New York Hospitals Cited Among Best in Death-Risk Study

docs.abstract: Fourth annual study by HealthGrades has only seven hospitals in New York State, and two in New York City, making list of hospitals in country where patients have lowest risk of death or serious complications; hospitals on list are New York-Presbyterian and Lutheran Medical Center (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: New York City, a leader in medical research, has the nation's densest concentration of hospitals and medical schools, many of them nationally renowned. So it is a pretty good place to get hospital care, right? In fact, only seven hospitals statewide -- and just two in the city -- made the list of hospitals in the country where patients have the lowest risk of death or serious complications, according to a report to be released today. The study, by HealthGrades, a health care analysis firm, is in its fourth year, and each year has yielded disappointing results for New York.
docs.snippet: Only two of the city's often vaunted hospitals  and just seven statewide  had the lowest risk for patients.

headline.print_headline: Diabetic Brothers Beat Odds With Grit and Luck
headline.main: Diabetic Brothers Beat Odds With Grit and Luck

docs.lead_paragraph: As diabetes poses a rapidly rising threat to Americans' health, the lives of two brothers from Syracuse offer the ultimate diabetic success story.
docs.snippet: As diabetes poses a rapidly rising threat to Americans' health, the lives of two brothers from Syracuse offer the ultimate diabetic success story.

docs.abstract: Editorial notes that US, only leading economic power without national health care, also leads world in per capita rate of diabetes; holds that care as basic as regular visits to nutritionist are not typically covered by insurance; says reimbursement is easier when disease is far along, and patient needs dialysis or amputation of toes or limbs; contends that waiting for this epidemic's fuller toll is foolhardy; asserts that now is time to develop coordinated plan with long view to take control of diabetes
docs.lead_paragraph: The recent four-part series in The Times offered grim insights into the incurable disease diabetes. Ignore it, and it can lead to heart disease, strokes, amputations and shortened lives. It is the leading cause of blindness. Most of those who have diabetes have Type 2, in which obesity and poverty are key contributors, especially among blacks and Hispanics, who are disproportionately stricken. It is not uncommon in poor and minority communities, the worst hit, to see amputees in wheelchairs. The neighborhoods where diabetes runs rampant are almost always short on parks for exercise and have schools that rarely conduct gym classes. Fast food restaurants abound; healthy food is often expensive or unavailable and bad diet choices -- laden with sugar, fat and calories -- are readily at hand. Diabetes is a disease defined by economic disparity. In heavily Hispanic East Harlem in Manhattan, the illness plagues 14 percent of the population; just to the south, across 96th Street on the more affluent Upper East Side, the rate is under 2 percent.
docs.snippet: Now is the time to develop a coordinated plan with a long view to take control of diabetes.

docs.abstract: Alexander Boldizar letter responds to Nicholas D Kristof's Jan 31 Op-Ed column; holds that root cause of obesity in America is not Coca Cola; says it is culture that is so alienated from everything natural that even body is chore and fitness is something to accomplish
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re Nicholas D. Kristof's Jan. 31 column about obesity, and his argument that we should use stairs instead of elevators:
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     Re Nicholas D. Kristof's Jan. 31 column about obesity, and his argument that we should use stairs instead of elevators:

headline.main: Whole Milk Is Out as Schools Fight Fat a Half Pint at a Time

docs.section_name: Front Page; Education; New York and Region
docs.lead_paragraph: For generations of children, a serving of whole milk, customarily in a red and white carton, has been as synonymous with school as a yellow No. 2 pencil. When President Harry S. Truman signed the National School Lunch Program into law in 1946, a half pint of milk was one of five dietary staples required by the bill. But children today are fat, or at least too many of them are, and to cut the risks of obesity, diabetes and other health problems, New York City -- the nation's largest school district -- has decided to cut whole milk from the menu.
docs.snippet: To reduce the risks of obesity, diabetes and other health problems, New York City has decided to serve one percent and skim milk.

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-14 Guilty Plea Is Expected In Iraq Corruption Case Federal court papers indicate that Robert J. Stein Jr., who was put in charge of at least $82 million of reconstruction money in Iraq, will plead guilty to conspiracy, bribery and other charges, for essentially giving millions of that money to another American businessman and taking millions more for himself. A1 The trial of Saddam Hussein resumed without him, after he and four other main defendants refused to attend and the judge decided to continue anyway. A10 Quake Victims Battle Winter Despite a large aid effort since an earthquake devastated Kashmir three months ago, there are villages still in need of basic assistance during the region's harsh winter. A1 Israeli Settlers and Police Clash More than 200 people were injured when Jewish settlers confronted Israeli police officers who had been ordered to tear down houses the settlers had built without government permission in the West Bank. A12 Egypt insisted that Hamas renounce violence, confirm existing agreements between Israel and the Palestinians and recognize Israel's legitimacy if it wants to form the next Palestinian government. A12 Iran Issue Moves Closer to U.N. Britain, France and Germany introduced a draft resolution asking the 35-nation board of the International Atomic Energy Agency to refer Iran's nuclear case to the United Nations Security Council. A6 Rift Over Cartoons Widens Several European newspapers reprinted cartoons depicting the Muslim prophet Muhammad in an unflattering light, supporting a Danish newspaper that inspired a huge outcry in the Islamic world by publishing them in the first place. A12 NATIONAL A15-20 Spending Bill Is Approved By Slim Margin in House House Republicans eked out a slim victory on a $39.5 billion budget-cutting package, helping President Bush deliver on his promise to rein in federal spending. A1 Requests on Spying Rebuffed The Bush administration is rebuffing requests from members of the Senate Judiciary Committee for its classified legal opinions on the president's domestic spying program. A1 Energy Plan Hits Hurdles The energy proposals set out by President Bush quickly ran into obstacles, showing how difficult it will be to take even the modest steps he supports to reduce the nation's reliance on foreign oil. A1 Miners Killed in West Virginia Just weeks after the death of 14 West Virginia miners, two more mine workers were killed in separate accidents, prompting Gov. Joe Manchin III to urge all coal companies in the state to cease operations until safety could be reviewed. A15 Alito's First Vote a Suprise Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. cast his first vote on the Supreme Court, splitting with his new boss, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr., and Justices Antonin Scalia and Clarence Thomas in a ruling that blocked the execution of a Missouri inmate. A19 Push for More Body Armor Military procurement officials told Congress that they were making every possible effort to speed the delivery of additional body armor to Iraq to protect the sides of soldier's torsos from insurgent attacks. A18 State of the Union Encore President Bush took his upbeat message on the road and promised ''an active foreign policy, one that aids the suffering and helps the poor'' around the world. A20 NEW YORK/REGION B1-8 Whole Milk Off the Menu At City's School Cafeterias The New York City schools, in an effort to curb obesity, diabetes and other health problems, have decided to cut whole milk from the lunch menu, putting an end to a staple of the school cafeteria since the Truman administration. A1 Move to Alter Laws on H.I.V. Thomas R. Frieden, left, the New York City health commissioner, called for changing state laws so that health officials can more aggressively test people for H.I.V./AIDS and also use the city's medical information to treat those infected. B1 Battle Over Princeton Name Princeton University is fighting a move by the brokerage firm Merrill Lynch & Company to use the Princeton name on its mutual funds, arguing that the company was trying to trade on the school's image as a bastion of higher education. B1 SPORTSTHURSDAY D1-6 HOUSE & HOME F1-8 THURSDAY STYLES G1-10 ARTS E1-12 OBITUARIES A21 Moira Shearer A luminous star in the galaxy of British ballerinas who brought the Royal Ballet to international attention, she was 80. A21 BUSINESS DAY C1-18 Indictments Expected The Justice Department and the Securities and Exchange Commission are expected to announce criminal and civil fraud charges against three former top executives at the General Reinsurance Corporation, a Berkshire Hathaway subsidiary, as well as a former senior executive of the American International Group, according to two people with direct knowledge of the charges. C1 Enron Testimony Begins Mark E. Koenig, former head of Enron's investor relations, testified at the criminal trial of the former chief executives Kenneth L. Lay and Jeffrey K. Skilling that the company fudged its quarterly earnings and repeatedly lied to Wall Street about the true condition of its troubled broadband services division to keep its stock price soaring. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A22-23 Editorials: Hamas at the helm; the march of the straw soldiers; seducing the medical profession; oh, Oscar! Columns: David Brooks, Bob Herbert.
